questions.question: Can the most variable numeric measurement in the game data be predicted by just a few other statistics? Return as JSON with keys: target, predictors, r_squared, adj_r_squared, n_significant, coefficients, p_values.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the highest variance, find its three strongest correlations, fit an OLS regression with those predictors, and report the model fit and significance.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "predictors" (list of 3 column names), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "adj_r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "n_significant" (integer count of predictors with p < 0.05), "coefficients" (dict mapping predictor names to coefficients rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_values" (dict mapping predictor names to p-values rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "predictors": ["sqft", "bedrooms", "age"], "r_squared": 0.7234, "adj_r_squared": 0.7156, "n_significant": 2, "coefficients": {"sqft": 123.45, "bedrooms": 5000.12, "age": -200.34}, "p_values": {"sqft": 0.000001, "bedrooms": 0.023456, "age": 0.156789}}

questions.question: Which numeric feature best predicts the column with the highest variance in this LoL dataset? Return as JSON with keys: target, best_predictor, correlation, r_squared, coefficient, p_value.
questions.hint: Identify the most variable column, compute absolute correlations with all other numeric columns, select the strongest, then fit a simple OLS regression.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "best_predictor" (column name), "correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "coefficient" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "best_predictor": "sqft", "correlation": 0.834, "r_squared": 0.6956, "coefficient": 135.2847, "p_value": 0.000001}

questions.question: Is there a numeric column in the dataset that follows a normal distribution?
questions.hint: Identify the column with the smallest absolute skewness, compute its mean and standard deviation, standardize the data, and run a Kolmogorov‑Smirnov test against a standard normal. Return as JSON with keys: column, ks_statistic, p_value, is_normal, sample_mean, sample_std.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (tested column), "ks_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "is_normal" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05), "sample_mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "sample_std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "height", "ks_statistic": 0.0456, "p_value": 0.234567, "is_normal": true, "sample_mean": 170.1234, "sample_std": 10.5678}

questions.question: Is there a significant difference in the distribution of the most skewed numeric column between high and low groups based on a median split? Return as JSON with keys: target_column, grouping_column, group1, group2, median1, median2, u_statistic, p_value.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with highest absolute skewness, create a binary grouping from another numeric column using its median, then compare the groups with a Mann‑Whitney U test.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 8 keys: "target_column", "grouping_column", "group1", "group2", "median1" (rounded to 4 decimals), "median2" (rounded to 4 decimals), "u_statistic" (rounded to 2 decimals), and "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target_column": "score", "grouping_column": "treatment", "group1": "control", "group2": "experimental", "median1": 72.5000, "median2": 78.0000, "u_statistic": 1234.50, "p_value": 0.034567}

questions.question: Which two numeric game statistics show the strongest monotonic relationship? Return as JSON with keys: columns, spearman_rho, p_value, interpretation.
questions.hint: Calculate the Spearman correlation matrix for all numeric columns and identify the pair with the highest absolute correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "spearman_rho" (correlation coefficient rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), and "interpretation" (string: "strong", "moderate", "weak", or "negligible"). Example: {"columns": ["age", "income"], "spearman_rho": 0.7234, "p_value": 0.000001, "interpretation": "strong"}

questions.question: Which two most skewed numeric features show the strongest relationship, and does applying a log transformation strengthen their correlation? Return as JSON with keys: columns, original_correlation, log_correlation, improvement, transformation_helpful.
questions.hint: Find the two numeric columns with highest absolute skewness, compute their Pearson correlation, then log‑transform the data (e.g., log1p) and recompute the correlation to see if the magnitude improves.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 5 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "original_correlation" (Pearson, rounded to 4 decimals), "log_correlation" (after log transform, rounded to 4 decimals), "improvement" (absolute difference, rounded to 4 decimals), and "transformation_helpful" (boolean, true if |log_corr| > |orig_corr|). Example: {"columns": ["income", "spending"], "original_correlation": 0.4567, "log_correlation": 0.7234, "improvement": 0.2667, "transformation_helpful": true}

questions.question: Which numeric feature from the first 10 minutes exhibits the highest variability across games, and does its distribution follow a normal pattern? Return as JSON with keys: distribution, median, iqr.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the greatest variance, perform a normality test (e.g., Shapiro‑Wilk), then report mean/std if normal or median/IQR if non‑normal.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 3 keys. If normal: {"distribution": "normal", "mean": <number>, "std": <number>}. If non-normal: {"distribution": "non-normal", "median": <number>, "iqr": <number>}. The "iqr" value is Q3 minus Q1 as a single number. All numeric values rounded to 3 decimal places.

questions.question: Which two early-game metrics are most strongly correlated, and does that relationship stay the same after removing extreme outliers? Return as JSON with keys: columns, original_correlation, outliers_removed, clean_correlation.
questions.hint: Find the pair with the highest absolute correlation, drop rows where either value is more than 3 standard deviations from its mean, then recompute the correlation on the cleaned data.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "original_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "outliers_removed" (integer count), and "clean_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "original_correlation": 0.847, "outliers_removed": 12, "clean_correlation": 0.891}

questions.question: How many columns contain outliers and what is the total number of outlier values in the dataset? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: Check each numeric column for values beyond 2.5 standard deviations from the mean.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: Which numeric measurement shows the greatest relative variability in the first 10 minutes of the game? Return as JSON with keys: column, cv, mean, std.
questions.hint: Compute the coefficient of variation (std/mean*100) for each numeric column and identify the column with the highest value.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "column" (name of column with highest CV), "cv" (coefficient of variation as percentage rounded to 2 decimals), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "price", "cv": 45.23, "mean": 1234.5678, "std": 558.4567}

questions.question: Which two numeric metrics are most strongly linearly related in the first 10 minutes of a game? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Compute the absolute correlation matrix of all numeric columns and identify the pair with the highest off‑diagonal correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the correlation coefficient rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.847}

questions.question: Which two numeric features in the early-game dataset show the weakest relationship? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Calculate the absolute correlation matrix for all numeric columns and locate the pair with the smallest non‑zero correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the absolute correlation value rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.012}

questions.question: Which numeric column has the highest variance in the first 10 minutes, and what is its mean value? Return as JSON with keys: mean.
questions.hint: Find the column with the greatest variance, then calculate its average.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the mean), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: Which numeric metric from the first 10 minutes has the lowest average value, and what is its variability? Return as JSON with keys: std.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the smallest mean, then compute its standard deviation.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the standard deviation), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: Are any of the game statistics missing in a substantial portion of matches? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the missing value percentage for each column and list those exceeding 5%.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Are there any columns in this dataset that have a high proportion of missing values? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Compute the percentage of missing entries for each column and identify those exceeding a chosen threshold (e.g., 10%).
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Which numeric field in the early game shows the greatest variability, and what are its key percentile values? Return as JSON with keys: column, p10, p25, p50, p75, p90.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the largest range, then compute its 10th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 90th percentiles.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "p10" (10th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "p25" (25th percentile), "p50" (median), "p75" (75th percentile), and "p90" (90th percentile). Example: {"column": "income", "p10": 25000.0000, "p25": 40000.0000, "p50": 55000.0000, "p75": 75000.0000, "p90": 100000.0000}

questions.question: Which numeric column shows the greatest variability, and what are its key descriptive statistics? Return as JSON with keys: column, count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, kurtosis.
questions.hint: Find the column with the highest variance, then compute its count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, and kurtosis.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 9 keys: "column", "count" (integer), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "std", "min", "max", "median", "skewness", and "kurtosis" (all rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "age", "count": 1000, "mean": 35.4567, "std": 12.3456, "min": 18.0000, "max": 85.0000, "median": 34.0000, "skewness": 0.5678, "kurtosis": -0.2345}
